wikipedia_page.main: George Horatio Cholmondeley, 2nd Marquess of Cholmondeley, PC (; 16 January 1792 – 8 May 1870), styled Viscount Malpas until 1792 and Earl of Rocksavage between 1792 and 1827, was a British peer and Lord Great Chamberlain of England between 1830 and 1838. Before being called to the House of Lords, he was a Tory Member of Parliament from 1817 through 1821.

response: * Lady Susan Carolina Somerset (10 May 1804 – 4 February 1886), married George Cholmondeley, 2nd Marquess of Cholmondeley.

This was originally a timber-framed chapel dating from the 13th century.  It was damaged in the civil war and, because of this and because of general dilapidation, it was repaired in 1652 by Robert Cholmondeley, 1st Earl of Leinster.  In 1717 the timber framing of the chancel was encased with brick and the rest of the chapel was rebuilt with brick and stone facings.  Transepts were added in 1829 by George Cholmondeley, 2nd Marquess of Cholmondeley, and north and south galleries were added in 1840.  Later in the 19th century George Gilbert Scott was asked to supply plans for the chapel's restoration, which included its demolition, apart from the chancel.  The Marquess declined to follow these plans and instead repairs were conducted by workmen from the estate.

response: * George Cholmondeley, 2nd Marquess of Cholmondeley (1792–1870), British peer and politician

Through the marriage between the earl and Georgina Bertie, the ancient hereditary office of Lord Great Chamberlain (which had been held by her brother, Robert Bertie, 4th Duke of Ancaster and Kesteven, until his death in 1779) passed into the Cholmondeley family. Notes and Queries (1883 Jan–Jun), p. 42. Georgina's son George Cholmondeley, 2nd Marquess of Cholmondeley, shared the position. Portcullis : Deed of Covenant and Agreement between Lord Willoughby de Eresby, The Dowager Marchioness of Cholmondeley and the Marquis of Cholmondeley re the exercise of the Office of Hereditary Great Chamberlain (16 May 1829).
